climbs.name: The Lotus Eater
climbs.fa: Bob Loomis, seconded by Bill Erler, 14 October 2007

content.description: As one enters the Glen the largest formation is on the left where the existing overhanging bolted hard routes are.  Just a bit around the corner and right of those overhanging routes is an overhanging finger, hand, and fist crack that takes good gear.  The crux is actually out of sight above the initial overhang.  On the first ascent a lot of moss was pulled out and lichen brushed off.  But due to disuse the route is now a bit overgrown with lichen, though the jams and footholds are still clean.  With a few repeat ascents the route will clean up.  A good route for a climber to built his/her harder crack climbing skills.
content.protection: Pro to 3 inches.  Several over the shoulder slings to extend gear is a good idea but not essential.  Natural gear at the top to set up an anchor.
content.location: As one enters the Glen the largest formation is on the left where the existing overhanging bolted hard routes are.  Just a bit around the corner on that same formation and slightly uphill and right of those overhanging routes is this route which follows an obvious overhanging dihedral in the corner of which is a finger, hand, and fist crack.

content.description: big moves lead to lye-back and jugs to top
